column4: it sounds like the problem is pretty deep; fdisk can't get at the partition table
that is, robert has tried 'sudo fdisk /dev/sdb' just to look at it more closely, and it failed attempting to 'hook' the drive
if the partition table is corrupted, it might do that, but you should still be able to pull an image
at very least with dd_rescue or dc3dd if there's corruption or certain kinds of physical damage
yes, cloning the drive with 'dd' is worth a try, i agree
what about just ripping sector 0 (partition table); are there any tools that can examine partition tables as bin files?
im not sure, im not a data recovery expert, i suppose if you know enough about partition tables, you can look at the hex
eh... i like assembly programming; that's as deep as i go in terms of "looking at hex" ;-)
ive had to do machine code programming before (for class, we didn't have an assembler because we were using a custom architecture), slogging through hex doesn't intimidate me anymore :P
i'm not as young as i used to be, and now getting *too* nitty-gritty isn't as spellbinding as it once was :-D
i was going to suggest a bash script... i assume you mean that you won't know exactly what they are, which would preclude adding them to fstab?
yeah, if they're consistent, fstab is by far the most correct tool
and sucks for just about everything else
getting the samba shares into my fstab was easier than i thought; i just had to find the syntax for samba-style (smbfs) file systems
the way linux handles file systems, it's not very hard to do
agreed, though it's a steep learning curve for the details (like fstab syntax, and so on)... well... IMO, anyway
